title: How to Roast a Goose

steps.headline: Put a 10-12 lb (4.5-5.5 k) goose in a pot and brine it with salt water overnight.
steps.description: Fill the pot with water and add approximately 1/4 cup (32 g) of salt to the water to create a brine. Refrigerate the pot with the goose and brine overnight. Remove it when you are ready to cook it the next day. The brine will help the goose stay extra moist while it cooks so that you don't end up with a dry roast goose.

steps.headline: Remove the goose from the brine and prick the skin with a fork.
steps.description: Place the goose on a cutting board or in a pan while you prepare it to cook. Prick the skin in several places to help the fat render down more easily while it cooks. Take care not to prick the flesh with the fork, only the skin. You can leave the goose in the pot that you brined it in if you want while you season it. Just make sure to thoroughly drain all of the water out of it.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C) and put the goose in a roasting pan.
steps.description: Place the goose breast-side-up on a rack in a shallow roasting pan. Wait for the oven to preheat. If you want to preheat the oven faster, turn the heat to 450 degrees F (230 C) first, then turn it down to 350 degrees F (175 C) right before you cook the goose.

steps.headline: Cut up 1 medium apple, 1 medium lemon and 1 medium orange.
steps.description: Cut the apple into rough chunks. Peel the lemon and orange and cut them into 4 pieces each. Don't worry too much about the size of the fruit pieces because you will discard them after you cook the goose. If you prefer, you can use a more traditional stuffing instead of fruit.

steps.headline: Season the goose with salt and pepper to taste, then stuff it with the fruit.
steps.description: Generously season the outside and inside of the goose before you fill the cavity with the fruit. Mix all of the fruit together in a large bowl first, then use your hand to stuff it inside of the goose. Use a good quality salt like kosher or sea salt and fresh-ground black pepper.

steps.headline: Cook the goose at 350 degrees F (175 C) for 2-3 hours.
steps.description: Put the roasting pan with the goose in the preheated oven and check the temperature with a cooking thermometer after 2 hours. Continue to cook it until the internal temperature reaches 180 degrees F (82 C). Make sure to insert the thermometer into the thickest part of the goose, right to the middle, to ensure that every part of it gets cooked thoroughly. For an extra-juicy goose, use a baster to baste it with the juices from the bottom of the pan every 30 minutes while it cooks.

steps.headline: Take the goose out of the oven, cover it with foil, and let it sit for 20 minutes.
steps.description: This will let all of the juices settle and disperse evenly throughout the goose. Remove and throw out the fruit before you carve the goose. Carve a goose the same way you would carve a turkey. Store any leftovers in the fridge for up to 4 days.

steps.headline: Prick the skin of the goose with a knife then pour boiling water over it.
steps.description: Poke holes in the skin of the goose in several places but be careful not to pierce the meat. Place the bird in a clean sink and carefully pour a pot or kettle of boiling water over it. Pierce the skin of the goose to help the high level of fat to render down faster. Pour boiling water over it to help tighten the skin so it gets super crispy.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C) and let the goose sit for 1 hour.
steps.description: Place the goose on a cutting board or in a pan and pat it dry with paper towels. Feel the skin of the goose after 1 hour. It is ready to cook when it has a dry and tacky feeling. Let the goose sit at room temperature, not in the fridge.

steps.headline: Put the goose in a roasting pan, season it with salt, and cover it with foil.
steps.description: Put the goose on a rack in a roasting tray and sprinkle it with salt all over to taste. Put a piece of tin foil over the whole tray and fold the edges under to secure it. Use kosher salt or sea salt to season the goose for the best, and tastiest, results!

steps.headline: Baste the goose every 30 minutes while it cooks.
steps.description: Carefully lift up part of the foil that is covering the goose and insert a baster to suck up some of the juice in the bottom of the pan. Squirt it evenly over the skin of the goose to baste it. Basting the goose will help the meat stay nice and moist.

steps.headline: Cook the goose for 1.5 to 2.5 hours depending on its weight.
steps.description: Cook a 10 lb (4.5 k) goose for 1.5-2 hours, an 11 lb (5 k) goose for 2-2.5 hours, and a 12 lb (5.5 k) goose for 2.5-3 hours. Remove the foil for approximately the last 30 minutes of cook time. Cook time can vary depending on your oven, so check the temperature of the goose every 30 minutes with a kitchen thermometer to see how close it is getting to 180 degrees F (82 C). If the temperature is getting close, and there is approximately 30 minutes left of cook time based on the weight of the goose, then remove the foil and finish cooking it until the temperature is at least 180 degrees F (82 C).

steps.headline: Remove the goose from the oven, cover it with foil, and let it sit for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Place the goose on a cutting board or leave it in the roasting pan on the counter. Re-cover it loosely with foil and let it sit to allow the juices to settle. You can carve a goose the same way you carve a turkey. Put any leftover goose in the fridge and keep them for up to 4 days.

text: Christmas Roast Goose Put a 10-12 lb (4.5-5.5 k) goose in a pot and brine it with salt water overnight. Fill the pot with water and add approximately 1/4 cup (32 g) of salt to the water to create a brine. Refrigerate the pot with the goose and brine overnight. Remove it when you are ready to cook it the next day. The brine will help the goose stay extra moist while it cooks so that you don't end up with a dry roast goose. Remove the goose from the brine and prick the skin with a fork. Place the goose on a cutting board or in a pan while you prepare it to cook. Prick the skin in several places to help the fat render down more easily while it cooks. Take care not to prick the flesh with the fork, only the skin. You can leave the goose in the pot that you brined it in if you want while you season it. Just make sure to thoroughly drain all of the water out of it. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C) and put the goose in a roasting pan. Place the goose breast-side-up on a rack in a shallow roasting pan. Wait for the oven to preheat. If you want to preheat the oven faster, turn the heat to 450 degrees F (230 C) first, then turn it down to 350 degrees F (175 C) right before you cook the goose. Cut up 1 medium apple, 1 medium lemon and 1 medium orange. Cut the apple into rough chunks. Peel the lemon and orange and cut them into 4 pieces each. Don't worry too much about the size of the fruit pieces because you will discard them after you cook the goose. If you prefer, you can use a more traditional stuffing instead of fruit. Season the goose with salt and pepper to taste, then stuff it with the fruit. Generously season the outside and inside of the goose before you fill the cavity with the fruit. Mix all of the fruit together in a large bowl first, then use your hand to stuff it inside of the goose. Use a good quality salt like kosher or sea salt and fresh-ground black pepper. Cook the goose at 350 degrees F (175 C) for 2-3 hours. Put the roasting pan with the goose in the preheated oven and check the temperature with a cooking thermometer after 2 hours. Continue to cook it until the internal temperature reaches 180 degrees F (82 C). Make sure to insert the thermometer into the thickest part of the goose, right to the middle, to ensure that every part of it gets cooked thoroughly. For an extra-juicy goose, use a baster to baste it with the juices from the bottom of the pan every 30 minutes while it cooks. Take the goose out of the oven, cover it with foil, and let it sit for 20 minutes. This will let all of the juices settle and disperse evenly throughout the goose. Remove and throw out the fruit before you carve the goose. Carve a goose the same way you would carve a turkey. Store any leftovers in the fridge for up to 4 days. Crispy Skin Roast Goose Prick the skin of the goose with a knife then pour boiling water over it. Poke holes in the skin of the goose in several places but be careful not to pierce the meat. Place the bird in a clean sink and carefully pour a pot or kettle of boiling water over it. Pierce the skin of the goose to help the high level of fat to render down faster. Pour boiling water over it to help tighten the skin so it gets super crispy. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C) and let the goose sit for 1 hour. Place the goose on a cutting board or in a pan and pat it dry with paper towels. Feel the skin of the goose after 1 hour. It is ready to cook when it has a dry and tacky feeling. Let the goose sit at room temperature, not in the fridge. Put the goose in a roasting pan, season it with salt, and cover it with foil. Put the goose on a rack in a roasting tray and sprinkle it with salt all over to taste. Put a piece of tin foil over the whole tray and fold the edges under to secure it. Use kosher salt or sea salt to season the goose for the best, and tastiest, results! Baste the goose every 30 minutes while it cooks. Carefully lift up part of the foil that is covering the goose and insert a baster to suck up some of the juice in the bottom of the pan. Squirt it evenly over the skin of the goose to baste it. Basting the goose will help the meat stay nice and moist. Cook the goose for 1.5 to 2.5 hours depending on its weight. Cook a 10 lb (4.5 k) goose for 1.5-2 hours, an 11 lb (5 k) goose for 2-2.5 hours, and a 12 lb (5.5 k) goose for 2.5-3 hours. Remove the foil for approximately the last 30 minutes of cook time. Cook time can vary depending on your oven, so check the temperature of the goose every 30 minutes with a kitchen thermometer to see how close it is getting to 180 degrees F (82 C). If the temperature is getting close, and there is approximately 30 minutes left of cook time based on the weight of the goose, then remove the foil and finish cooking it until the temperature is at least 180 degrees F (82 C). Remove the goose from the oven, cover it with foil, and let it sit for 30 minutes. Place the goose on a cutting board or leave it in the roasting pan on the counter. Re-cover it loosely with foil and let it sit to allow the juices to settle. You can carve a goose the same way you carve a turkey. Put any leftover goose in the fridge and keep them for up to 4 days.

Cut the apple into rough chunks.

Don't worry too much about the size of the fruit pieces because you will discard them after you cook the goose.
If you prefer, you can use a more traditional stuffing instead of fruit.

Generously season the outside and inside of the goose before you fill the cavity with the fruit.
Mix all of the fruit together in a large bowl first, then use your hand to stuff it inside of the goose.
Use a good quality salt like kosher or sea salt and fresh-ground black pepper.
Cook the goose at 350 degrees F (175 C) for 2-3 hours.
Put the roasting pan with the goose in the preheated oven and check the temperature with a cooking thermometer after 2 hours.
Continue to cook it until the internal temperature reaches 180 degrees F (82 C).
Make sure to insert the thermometer into the thickest part of the goose, right to the middle, to ensure that every part of it gets cooked thoroughly.

Crispy Skin Roast Goose Prick the skin of the goose with a knife then pour boiling water over it.

Pierce the skin of the goose to help the high level of fat to render down faster.
Pour boiling water over it to help tighten the skin so it gets super crispy.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C) and let the goose sit for 1 hour.
Place the goose on a cutting board or in a pan and pat it dry with paper towels.
Feel the skin of the goose after 1 hour.
It is ready to cook when it has a dry and tacky feeling.
Let the goose sit at room temperature, not in the fridge.
Put the goose in a roasting pan, season it with salt, and cover it with foil.
Put the goose on a rack in a roasting tray and sprinkle it with salt all over to taste.
Put a piece of tin foil over the whole tray and fold the edges under to secure it.

Baste the goose every 30 minutes while it cooks.
Carefully lift up part of the foil that is covering the goose and insert a baster to suck up some of the juice in the bottom of the pan.
Squirt it evenly over the skin of the goose to baste it.
Basting the goose will help the meat stay nice and moist.
Cook the goose for 1.5 to 2.5 hours depending on its weight.
Cook a 10 lb (4.5 k) goose for 1.5-2 hours, an 11 lb (5 k) goose for 2-2.5 hours, and a 12 lb (5.5 k) goose for 2.5-3 hours.
Remove the foil for approximately the last 30 minutes of cook time.
Cook time can vary depending on your oven, so check the temperature of the goose every 30 minutes with a kitchen thermometer to see how close it is getting to 180 degrees F (82 C).

If the temperature is getting close, and there is approximately 30 minutes left of cook time based on the weight of the goose, then remove the foil and finish cooking it until the temperature is at least 180 degrees F (82 C).
Remove the goose from the oven, cover it with foil, and let it sit for 30 minutes.
Place the goose on a cutting board or leave it in the roasting pan on the counter.
Re-cover it loosely with foil and let it sit to allow the juices to settle.
You can carve a goose the same way you carve a turkey.
Put any leftover goose in the fridge and keep them for up to 4 days.
